dataset.title: Flux measurements from the SRS-6 Tower, Shark River Slough, Everglades National Park, South Florida from January 2004 to December 2004

abstract.para: Above canopy measurements of carbon dioxide fluxes and sensible and latent heating were obtained with an open path eddy covariance system positioned on the tower at 26-m. Additionally, measurements of solar irradiance, wind speed, air temperature and humidity were made every half hour.

intellectualRights.para: These data are classified as 'Type 4' whereby the data collected are related to the FCE LTER Program but not funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) LTER Grant #9910514. These data are available for scientific purposes no more than 4 years after collection. Recommended maximum lock period = 2 years. In some cases, these data are funded by other agencies but the data are tied to the LTER objectives or were collected at FCE sites. In these cases, the researchers are strongly encouraged to either a) submit links to their databases, allowing direct connection to their web accessible data via the FCE LTER website and through the FCE Database, or b) to also submit their data to the FCE Information Manager at the time they are released to the agency. In either case, the researcher should seek permission of the agency in question to make this link. In these cases, the recommended lock period is identical to that mandated by the funding agency. All publications based on this dataset must cite the data Contributor, the Florida Coastal Everglades Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER) Program. Additionally, two copies of the manuscript must be submitted to the Florida Coastal Everglades LTER Program Office, LTER Program Manager, Southeast Environmental Research Center, OE 148, University Park, Florida International University, Miami, Florida 33199. For a complete description of the FCE LTER Data Distribution and Data User Agreement, please go to FCE Data Management Policy at http://fcelter.fiu.edu/data/data_mgmt_policy.html.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Data were collected the SRS6 Tower, Shark River Slough, Everglades National Park, South Florida
Florida Coastal Everglades LTER Study Area: South Florida, Everglades National Park, and Florida Bay

description.para: This is a short-term primary production dataset and subsequent data and metadata updates will be assigned a new file version number
The eddy covariance method (Dennis Baldocchi at Cal Berkeley)

citation.title: Assessing the eddy covariance technique for evaluating carbon dioxide exchange rates of ecosystems: past, present and future

methodStep.instrumentation: Flux tower and a listing of additional instrumentation can be found at http://www.people.virginia.edu/%7Ejf6s/pace/VFRFInstruments.html.

description.para: The Study Extent of this dataset includes the SRS6 research site, Shark River Slough, Everglades National Park, South Florida

samplingDescription.para: Fluxes are determined as half hour averages of 10 Hz covariance measurements of vertical wind speed and the scalar of interest (e.g. CO2).

description.para: Dataset is inspected by PI for QA/QC; standard validation checks for negative numbers, graphs to detect potential outliers .

project.title: Florida Coastal Everglades LTER: Coastal Oligotrophic Ecosystems Research-the Coastal Everglades

abstract.para: We are investigating how variability in regional climate, freshwater inputs, disturbance, and perturbations affect the coastal Everglades ecosystem. Our long term research program focuses on testing the following central idea and hypotheses: Regional processes mediated by water flow control population and ecosystem level dynamics at any location within the coastal Everglades landscape. This phenomenon is best exemplified in the dynamics of an estuarine oligohaline zone where fresh water draining phosphorus-limited Everglades marshes mixes with water from the more nitrogen-limited coastal ocean. Hypothesis 1: In nutrient-poor coastal systems, long-term changes in the quantity or quality of organic matter inputs will exert strong and direct controls on estuarine productivity, because inorganic nutrients are at such low levels. Hypothesis 2: Interannual and long-term changes in freshwater flow controls the magnitude of nutrients and organic matter inputs to the estuarine zone, while ecological processes in the freshwater marsh and coastal ocean control the quality and characteristics of those inputs. Hypothesis 3: Long-term changes in freshwater flow (primarily manifest through management and Everglades restoration) will interact with long-term changes in the climatic and disturbance (sea level rise, hurricanes, fires) regimes to modify ecological pattern and process across coastal landscapes.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: The FCE LTER Project Study area is located in South Florida, mostly in Everglades National Park. There are a total of 21 sampling sites located in two major regions: 1) Shark River Slough and 2) Taylor Slough/Panhandle.

dataTable.entityDescription: Flux measurements from the SRS-6 Tower, Shark River Slough, Everglades National Park, South Florida from January 2004 to December 2004

ns2:unit.name: percent
ns2:unit.ns2:description: ratio of two quantities as percent composition (1:100)

datasetSubmissionNotes.notes: 1. All quantities are half hour averages, and the time provided is the starting period. So, for time = 0, data is averaged from 0:00 to 0:30 hours. 2. During some periods, rain events produce invalid fluxes (for sensible and latent heat and CO2 flux). I replaced these values with zeros whenever possible. 3. Sometimes the air temperature measurement at 35 feet produces some spikes. I have not changed or eliminated these values because I usually take care of that in post-processing programs. 4. The quantum sensor that provides incoming photosynthetically active irradiance is often shaded sometime during the day because my boom on the tower is too short. I recommend just using solar irradiance to estimate this quantity. However, incoming photosynthetically active irradiance could still be useful if the data is properly filtered (but it would be a pain). 5. As you can imagine, it is not easy to really clean up this data set. I would just encourage someone using the data to take a close look at the diurnal profiles of any variable before proceeding.

datasetInfoManagementNotes.notes: 1) Changed Column Field Names to DayofYear, Time, Sensible_Heat_Flux, Latent_Heat _Flux, CO2_Flux, Friction_Velocity, Solar_Irradiance_Incident, Solar_Irradiance_Incident_STD, Solar_Irradiance_Reflected, Solar_Irradiance_Reflected_STD, Photosyn_Active_Irradiance_Incident, Photosyn_Active_Irradiance_Incident_STD, Photosyn_Active_Irradiance_Reflected, Photosyn_Active_Irradiance_Reflected_STD, Net_Irradiance , Net_Irradiance_STD, Tair_87ft, Tair_87ft_STD, RH, RH_STD, SH, SH_STD, Ws_27m, Ws_27m_STD, Wdir_27m, Wdir_27m_STD, Soil_Heat_Flux_5cm, Soil_Heat_Flux_5cm_STD, Tair_65ft, Tair_65ft_STD, Tair_50ft, Tair_50ft_STD, Tair_35ft, Tair_35ft_STD, Tair_20ft, Tair_20ft_STD, Tair_5ft, Tair_5ft_STD, Tsoil_2cm, Tsoil_2cm_STD, Tsoil_10cm, Tsoil_10cm_STD, Tsoil_20cm, Tsoil_20cm_STD, Tsoil_50cm, Tsoil_50cm_STD and 2) Converted all N/A entries to -9999.
